intro: Brassica nigra f. hispida, commonly known as the rough black mustard, is a cultivar of the mustard plant characterized by its dark, glossy leaves and dark purple or black seed pods. It is a member of the Brassicaceae family, which includes other cruciferous plants like broccoli and cabbage. The plant typically grows to a height of about 30–60 cm and thrives in temperate climates. Its hairy or rough texture on the leaves and stems is a distinguishing feature of this variety. The seeds are often used in traditional medicine and as a spice due to their pungent flavor.
